title: Corbyn expected to join Privy Council
text:
Labour says Corbyn will join Privy Council Kate Allen and Jim Pickard ©FT 
Labour insisted that Jeremy Corbyn would eventually become a member of the Privy Council, despite his longstanding republican sympathies, after he missed his first meeting of the august group. 
The new leader of the opposition had been expected to attend the council on Thursday, where his membership would have been approve after a traditional swearing-in ceremony. More BBC defends its light entertainment role 
Instead Mr Corbyn missed the meeting, sending apologies via his spokesman, as he is thought to be taking a short holiday before parliament reconvenes next week. 
The ancient body, which dates to the court of the Norman kings, has 600 members who advise the monarch at meetings roughly once a month. 
By joining it Mr Corbyn would gain access to a range of sensitive information including foreign affairs and policing and security matters. 
When becoming a Privy Council member it is traditional for politicians to bow to the Queen and kiss her hand. 
The Labour leader, who is a longstanding republican, has refused to say whether or not he would kneel in front of the monarch. 
Such uncertainty has played into wider criticism of his unconventional stances on a range of issues — for example describing the extra-judicial killing of Osama bin Laden as a “tragedy”. 
This week, David Cameron, the prime minister, used his speech to the Tory conference to call Mr Corbyn a “security threatening, terrorist-sympathising, Britain-hating” ideologue. 
Mr Corbyn, who has spent three decades as a protester on the backbenches, must now decide how much ground to cede on his principles as leader of Britain’s second-largest political party. 
He has also equivocated on wearing a red poppy to the annual remembrance service at the Cenotaph next month. Mr Cobyn has in past years also worn the pacifist symbol of a white poppy. Last month, his aides said he would only wear a red poppy this year. 
Mr Cameron also missed his first Privy Council meeting when he joined the body in 2005 as the newly elected leader of the Conservative party, which was in opposition at the time. Mr Cameron was not sworn in until three months after his membership was approved. 
A spokesperson for Mr Corbyn said: “Although Jeremy was unavailable for today’s meeting, he has confirmed he will be joining the Privy Council. As the prime minister and others did, it is far from unusual to miss the first meeting due to other commitments.” 
Mr Corbyn won the Labour leadership contest in a shock result after mustering a groundswell of support from new Labour members and those who signed up to vote in the contest through the party’s £3 supporter scheme. 
The team which masterminded his victorious campaign revealed on Thursday that they are converting it into a new local activist network, dubbed Momentum. 
Although the grassroots group will not stand candidates or act as a bloc vote in contests for internal Labour party positions, it intends to create “a mass movement for social change”. 
But the plans prompted alarm among more rightwing factions within the Labour party. 
Luke Akehurst, secretary of the more rightwing “Labour First”, criticised the “divisive” creation of the new group as a “parallel structure” outside the party. 
He warned that it could be part of an attempt to remove moderate councillors and MPs disliked by “veteran Bennite organisers”. 
Labour has signed up more than 180,000 new members since it lost the general election in May, approximately doubling the size of the party. 
But some leading figures in the Momentum network fear that the new members may lose motivation unless their energies can be channelled into frontline campaigning. Related Topics
